name: Auquan
Intervention assumptions: These projections do not make specific assumptions about which interventions have been implemented or will remain in place.

name: Ensemble
Intervention assumptions: The national and state-level ensemble forecasts include models that assume certain social distancing measures will continue and models that assume those measures will not continue.
Methods:: Equal-weighted combination of 2 to 11 models, depending on the availability of national and state-level forecasts. To ensure consistency, the ensemble includes only models with 4 week-ahead forecasts and models that do not assign a significant probability to there being fewer cumulative deaths than have already been reported. Only one model was available for the forecasts for Guam and the Northern Mariana Islands.

name: Columbia
Intervention assumptions: This model is based on assumptions about how levels of social distancing will change in the future.  It assumes a 20% reduction in contact rates for each successive week that stay-at-home orders remain in place or are expected to remain in place. Once a state has re-opened, contact rates are assumed to increase by 5% each week.

name: Geneva
Description: University of Geneva / Swiss Data Science Center
Intervention assumptions: The projections assume that social distancing policies in place at the date of calibration are extended for the future weeks.
Methods:: Exponential and linear statistical models fit to the recent growth rate of cumulative deaths.

name: GA_Tech
Description: Georgia Institute of Technology, College of Computing
Intervention assumptions: This model assumes that the effects of interventions are reflected in the observed data and will continue going forward.

name: Imperial
Intervention assumptions: These projections do not make specific assumptions about which interventions have been implemented or will remain in place.
Methods:: Ensembles of mechanistic transmission models, fit to different parameter assumptions.

name: ISU
Intervention assumptions: These projections do not make specific assumptions about which interventions have been implemented or will remain in place.

name: JHU
Intervention assumptions: This model assumes that the effectiveness of interventions is reduced after shelter-in-place orders are lifted.

name: LANL
Intervention assumptions: This model assumes that currently implemented interventions and corresponding reductions in transmission will continue, resulting in an overall decrease in the growth rate of COVID-19 deaths.
Methods:: Statistical dynamical growth model accounting for population susceptibility

name: MIT
Intervention assumptions: The projections assume that current interventions will remain in place indefinitely.

name: MOBS
Description: Northeastern University, Laboratory for the Modeling of Biological and Socio-technical Systems
Intervention assumptions: The projections assume that social distancing policies in place at the date of calibration are extended for the future weeks.

name: UA
Intervention assumptions: This model assumes that current interventions will remain in effect for at least four weeks after the forecasts are made

name: UCLA
Intervention assumptions: These projections assume that current interventions will not change during the forecasted period.

name: UMass-MB
Intervention assumptions: These projections do not make specific assumptions about which interventions have been implemented or will remain in place.

name: ERDC
Description: US Army Engineer Research and Development Center
Intervention assumptions: These projections assume that current interventions will not change during the forecasted period.

name: UT
Intervention assumptions: This model estimates the extent of social distancing using geolocation data from mobile phones and assumes that the extent of social distancing will not change during the period of forecasting. The model is designed to predict confirmed COVID-19 deaths resulting from only a single wave of transmission.
Methods:: Nonlinear Bayesian hierarchical regression with a negative-binomial model for daily variation in death rates

name: YYG
Intervention assumptions: The model accounts for individual state-by-state re-openings and their impact on infections and deaths.

name: CAN
Intervention assumptions: These projections do not make specific assumptions about which interventions have been implemented or will remain in place.

name: IHME
Description: Institute of Health Metrics and Evaluation
Intervention assumptions: Projections are adjusted to reflect differences in aggregate population mobility and community mitigation policies.
Methods:: Combination of a mechanistic disease transmission model and a curve-fitting approach

name: Imperial1
Intervention assumptions: These projections do not make any specific assumptions about which interventions have been or will remain in place.
Methods:: Ensembles of mechanistic transmission models, fit to different parameter assumptions.

name: Imperial2
Intervention assumptions: These projections do not make any specific assumptions about which interventions have been or will remain in place.
Methods:: Ensembles of mechanistic transmission models, fit to different parameter assumptions.

name: NotreDame
Intervention assumptions: The model accounts for each state’s school-closure and stay-at-home policies.

name: UChicago_10
Intervention assumptions: These forecasts assume that the transmission rate will increase by 10% when stay-at-home policies are lifted.

name: UChicago_100
Intervention assumptions: These forecasts assume a reduction in social contacts of 100%, 80%, 60%, or 40% for the projected time period.

name: UChicago_40
Intervention assumptions: These forecasts assume a reduction in social contacts of 100%, 80%, 60%, or 40% for the projected time period.

name: UChicago_60
Intervention assumptions: These forecasts assume a reduction in social contacts of 100%, 80%, 60%, or 40% for the projected time period.

name: UChicago_80
Intervention assumptions: These forecasts assume a reduction in social contacts of 100%, 80%, 60%, or 40% for the projected time period.

name: CU-80contact
Intervention assumptions: These models are based on assumptions about how levels of social distancing will change in the future. All start by assuming a weekly 20% reduction in the contact rate for each week when the epidemic growth rate is increasing. Additionally, the CU-20-1x and CU-20W models assume a 10% increase in contact rates once businesses re-open, applied either at one time or weekly, respectively.

name: CU-80contact_1x
Intervention assumptions: These models are based on assumptions about how levels of social distancing will change in the future. All start by assuming a weekly 20% reduction in the contact rate for each week when the epidemic growth rate is increasing. Additionally, the CU-20-1x and CU-20W models assume a 10% increase in contact rates once businesses re-open, applied either at one time or weekly, respectively.

name: CU-80contactw
Intervention assumptions: These models are based on assumptions about how levels of social distancing will change in the future. All start by assuming a weekly 20% reduction in the contact rate for each week when the epidemic growth rate is increasing. Additionally, the CU-20-1x and CU-20W models assume a 10% increase in contact rates once businesses re-open, applied either at one time or weekly, respectively.

name: CU-60contact
Intervention assumptions: These models are based on assumptions about how levels of social distancing will change in the future. All start by assuming a weekly 20% reduction in the contact rate for each week when the epidemic growth rate is increasing. Additionally, the CU-20-1x and CU-20W models assume a 10% increase in contact rates once businesses re-open, applied either at one time or weekly, respectively.

name: CU-70contact
Intervention assumptions: These models are based on assumptions about how levels of social distancing will change in the future. All start by assuming a weekly 20% reduction in the contact rate for each week when the epidemic growth rate is increasing. Additionally, the CU-20-1x and CU-20W models assume a 10% increase in contact rates once businesses re-open, applied either at one time or weekly, respectively.

name: CU 40% contact reduction
Intervention assumptions: These models are based on assumptions of reducing the number of contacts per case. Three different adaptive scenarios of contact reduction are projected: 20%, 30%, and 40% contact reduction in US counties with at least 10 cases. Additional reductions are implemented with additional new cases, and all social distancing interventions remain in place until the end of the projection.

name: CU 30% contact reduction
Intervention assumptions: These models are based on assumptions of reducing the number of contacts per case. Three different adaptive scenarios of contact reduction are projected: 20%, 30%, and 40% contact reduction in US counties with at least 10 cases. Additional reductions are implemented with additional new cases, and all social distancing interventions remain in place until the end of the projection.

name: CU 20% contact reduction
Intervention assumptions: These models are based on assumptions of reducing the number of contacts per case. Three different adaptive scenarios of contact reduction are projected: 20%, 30%, and 40% contact reduction in US counties with at least 10 cases. Additional reductions are implemented with additional new cases, and all social distancing interventions remain in place until the end of the projection.

name: CovidSim
Intervention assumptions: These projections assume that contact rates will increase by 20% after stay-at-home orders are lifted.

name: GT_CHHS
Description: Georgia Institute of Technology, Center for Health and Humanitarian Systems
Intervention assumptions: This model assumes that once stay-at-home orders are lifted, contact rates will gradually increase.  It also assumes that households containing symptomatic cases will self-quarantine.

name: PSI
Intervention assumptions: These projections assume that current interventions will not change during the forecasted period.

name: SWC
Intervention assumptions: These projections do not make specific assumptions about which interventions have been implemented or will remain in place.
